conclusion: Determine the height h_a from which the ball a must be released so that it can just fly out from point D.
The ball starts from rest at point P and slides down the inclined rail PA. The angle between the inclined rail and the horizontal is θ = 53°.
Using conservation of energy: mgh_a = (1/2)mv_A^2 where v_A is the velocity at point A.
At point B, the ball transitions from the inclined rail to the horizontal rail AB.
Since the rails are smooth, the ball's speed remains the same as it reaches point B: v_B = v_A.
The ball then moves along the semicircular track BCD and needs to have enough speed to just fly out from point D.
At point D, the ball will have both tangential and radial components of velocity. For the ball to just fly out from point D, its radial component of velocity at point D must be zero.
The tangential component of velocity at point D is given by: v_D = v_B.
The ball loses some kinetic energy due to the electric field force acting on it while moving along the horizontal rail AB and the semicircular track BCD.
The work done by the electric field force over the horizontal distance AB is: W_E = -qEx.
Since the ball just flies out from point D, the total kinetic energy at point D must be sufficient to overcome the potential energy at point D and still have enough speed to move horizontally.
Using the conservation of energy: mgh_a = (1/2)mv_D^2 + mg(2R) where R is the radius of the semicircular track.
Since the ball just flies out from point D, the tangential component of velocity at point D must be equal to the horizontal component of the velocity after leaving point D.
Thus, the height h_a can be calculated as: h_a = 2R + (v_D^2)/(2g).
